p: Salvia officinalis subsp. lavandulifolia has similar uses in Valencia region, where it is known as sàlvia, sàlvia de serra, sàvia, sava, sèrvia, and sèlvia. Infrequent uses, are related to eye, skin, or the musculoskeletal or nervous system. In Castellón province, it is used in inhalation fumes for migraines, as ophthalmic antiinflamatory and for rheumatism. In the Aragonese borderlands, this sage is less frequent and less cited, although it is highly prized; it is known as sàlvia, sàlvia d'Aragó, estepera, and as salvia de Penyagolosa (mountain of Valencia region where it is collected). The main traditional uses in Aragon are as digestive and depurative, and it is considered very effective against menstrual problems and to eliminate the bad odor of the feet. In Murcia region, S. officinalis subsp. lavandulifolia is locally known as manisierva, manisielva, marisielva, mariselva, mariserva, marisierva, salvia, and savia. It is used for the same purposes cited above, but also as aperitif (Obón and Rivera, 1991) and as masticatory to clean the teeth. The last use is also found in Albacete (Castilla—La Mancha), where, macerated in alcohol, is additionally employed for rubbing back and chest to relieve fatigue. The decoction has been used as gargle for snoring and sore throats (Verde et al., 2008). In Albacete, bordering Valencia region, this species and the hybrid S. x hegelamieri, are indistinctly employed. For S. officinalis subsp. lavandulifolia, some popular names, marisielva, marisilva, salvia, savia, selva, sielva, and sierva, resemble to those collected in Murcia and Valencia regions.
